results.description:
Be part of creating a better future.


A six-weekend format for the internationally-recognized full Permaculture Design Certificate Course (PDC), running January through May 2016 at the beautiful Boston Nature Center!  

This PDC is a great value:  13 full days, more than 120 direct contact hours with experienced permaculture designers, facilitators and teachers... all for about $100 per day! Discount ideas can be found below.

This course, which will carry an urban and suburban focus, is recommended for home-owners and renters, educators, school garden organizers, farmers and gardeners, activists, landscape professionals, planners, architects, engineers, tradespeople and anyone interested in charting a new course for themselves and their communities.

This course is co-sponsored by Mass Audubon's Boston Nature Center, The Boston Food Forest Coalition, and the Greater Boston Permaculture Guild.

FULL COURSE DETAILS BELOW

Expected Outcomes:


• Gain a thorough understanding of permaculture origins, ethics, principles and design methodologies.

• Enhance your ability to build soil, capture water, reduce energy consumption, generate energy, grow and store food, read the landscape and create edible perennial ecosystems.

• Become a resource for your family and neighborhood, building resilience at the personal, household, enterprise and community levels.

• Be able to approach any piece of land and apply a permaculture design methodology and set of applied techniques to achieve increased resilience and true sustainability.

• Learn how to start transforming even challenging properties into healthy, high-yielding systems of abundance that require little to no fossil fuels.

• Change the way you view the challenges around you.

Read Testimonials from Past PDC Participants


2016 Permaculture Design Certificate Course Details

Where: This course will take place at Mass Audubon's Boston Nature Center in Mattapan (Boston), MA; the site will also be base camp from which we'll make several field trips to sites relevant to permaculture.  Plenty of on-site parking.

When: This course will be held over the course of six weekends (including one final 3-day weekend), January through May 2016. 

Course dates are:  Jan 9/10, Feb 6/7, Mar 5/6, April 2/3, Apr 30/May 1, FINAL 3-day DESIGN WEEKEND May 20/21/22.  Plus hold March 19/20 as a "make-up date" in case we get snowed out earlier in the course.  This works well for those who cannot take extensive time off from work or home responsibilities. *Final confirmation of the April dates is coming in June.

Class time generally runs 9am to 7pm on Saturday and 9am to 5pm on Sunday of each weekend.  Local homestays can be arranged if travelling a distance to attend this course.

Cost: $1300 Early Price (if paid in full by October 15th), $1400 if completing payment after October 15th.

Course fee includes full course materials and certification, coffee, tea + am/pm snacks and refreshments, handouts, over 30 gigabytes of course reference materials (digital format), access to the 200+ volume physical permaculture library, field trips, guest instructors. One hearty organic evening meal per weekend is provided and lunches will be potluck/BYO in order to keep the course fee down.  $250 Deposit holds your spot in this course.

People of Color and Native People are encouraged to contact Lisa Fernandes to discuss the special $250 total course fee per person. 


Want to reduce your fee?

• Register and pay in full by October 15th, 2015 ($100 off course fee)

• For every full course participant who says you referred them, receive $50 off your total tuition for this course.

• Consider becoming a Community-Supported-Permaculturist by fund raising a portion of your course fee.  Here is a sample fund raising letter that you can modify to suit your needs.  Become a resource for your community!

Class Size is limited.  This course typically sells out.

What: This course consists of the traditional 72-hour PDC course + approx 40 additional hours = well over 120 contact hours (+ homework and self-directed study) to ensure we cover hands-on activities, regional examples and timely developments. You will participate in this course through a combination of lecture, hands-on exercises, guest speakers, field trips, homework, video, discussion and a group student design project. There will be pre-work (short readings and some video) before the course and 2-3 hours of "homework" between course weekends. Students must attend all sessions and complete the group design project on the final weekend in order to receive their certificates of completion.

Use this page to register online and make your deposit with a credit/debit/prepaid card or PayPal. Alternatively, use this form to send a check! Remember, $100 off if fully paid by October 15th, 2015!

There are two recommended texts and two articles to read before the start of this course. Please visit  http://www.postwire.com/page/508a86a85e0e1f02e80000b6 for details on the prework. Thanks!

Topics Include (but not limited to...)

Permaculture Background & Context

Permaculture Ethics & Principles

Patterns in Nature / Pattern Literacy

Reading the Landscape (Multiple Modalities)

Site Assessment & Analysis (Multiple Modalities)

Living Soils & Soil Health

Water and Earthworks Techniques

Urban Soils & Soil Remediation

Sheet Mulching Techniques

"Synergistic Garden" & Fukuoka Methods

Robust Permaculture Design Process

Viewing a Property Through a Permaculture Lens

Permaculture Plants for the Northeast

Polyculture Design, Guilds and Food Forestry

Urban Agroforestry

Animals in the Landscape

Biodynamics & Permaculture

Renewable Energy Strategies

Retrofitting Buildings for Resilience

Affordable Green Building/Examples

Retrofitting Existing Neighborhoods

Social & Financial Permaculture

Urban Permaculture Applications

Becoming Permaculture Resources in Your Community

Design Methodologies and Conventions

Permaculture Connections to the World

Design Practicum + Presentations

Carrying Permaculture Forward


Facilitation team includes:  Boston native Lisa Fernandes, Jesse Watson (of Midcoast Permaculture), Mark Krawczyk (of Keyline Vermont and Burlington Permaculture), Kiarna Boyd, Rachel Lyn Rumson, Kim Almeida and many other guest experts from our regional network joining along the way to provide a high-quality learning experience tailored to our region.

results.description:
Their major issue is that they have tons of donations, and not even close enough amount of volunteers, to sort useable vs. recycle goods.  

http://thewishproject.org/ 

The Wish Project is a non-profit dedicated to providing free furniture, home goods, baby goods, and clothing to people in need in the Merrimack Valley, primarily through reuse and recycling. They serve thousands of people each year, and rely on the help of many volunteers. Let's be some of those volunteers! We'll take on whatever task they need on this day, but generally it involves sorting and organizing donations so they can be given out to clients. Children ages 8+ are welcome to join the effort. It's a great opportunity to teach your kids compassion in a very hands-on way. 

IMPORTANT:

If you are bringing children, please make a note in the comments section so I can give the Wish Project an accurate count of adults and kids who will be attending.

http://thewishproject.org/

 *PLEASE NOTE:  When you RSVP 'yes' it becomes a commitment. I am in contact with the volunteer coordinator, Patty, whom is now a member, giving her a head count. She then creates a list of things that need to be done -relying upon the number of volunteers. If your plans change, please be considerate -take a moment to update your RSVP to 'no.' It's very simple- and greatly appreciated! Thanks :)
results.how_to_find_us: The WORD is out, n' spreading!

Starting 2016 off with a bang, who wants to go see The Forest?  Looks like it'll be a nice creepy story.  If you are interested, Mike Lupi, a member of this meetup, is planning on going to the 10:30 am showing of The Forest this Saturday at the AMC Assembly Row.  Afterwards, the plan is to grab a bite to eat at one of the many restaurants there at Assembly Row.

Every Saturday morning at 10:00 AM we gather for a fun, calming group run at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir. Both walkers and runners are welcome. Our main goal is to socialize and support one another!

The Boston Bulldogs is a co-ed non-profit running club founded to support those battling addiction and in recovery, those who have been affected by addiction and their supporters.

We welcome and encourage runners of all levels – dreamers, beginners, as well as those with running experience, past or present. Our volunteer runners will be there to coach you at your current level, and help you meet your goals. We might even be able to help with running gear if needed. 

We meet twice weekly at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir (Cleveland Circle/Reservoir Green Line C or D train) -- on Saturday mornings at 10:00 AM and Thursday evenings at 6:30 PM. We first gather in front of the Cleveland Circle Starbucks, before heading over to the reservoir. See you there!

If you are interested in becoming a member or a volunteer, in making a contribution to the Club, in sponsoring a runner in recovery, or in learning more about the Boston Bulldog educational wellness/running program, contact us at:

• Website - BostonBulldogsRunning.com

• Email - [masked]

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

results.description:
This holiday season, the number one gift under the tree is going to be a multirotor, drone, UAS, what-ever you want to call it. They will be large and small, for children young and old. This is a sure sign that our passion for this technology is going mainstream. In the long term, this is great news: the more people who have first-hand experience with these systems, the easier it becomes for us to argue for their safe, beneficial and non-intrusive use in society.


However, in the short term, it means that a quarter of a million novice pilots are about to take to the skies. As enthusiasts and proponents for this technology, we feel that we owe it to them — and to ourselves, and to the future of this industry — to do everything we can to help them get started on the right foot.

The goal is a nationwide effort to have these new pilots meet with experienced amateurs and professionals to learn how to fly as well as how to fly safely.

We encourage those who received a new drone as a gift for the holidays to bring it with them to the event and ask questions and hopefully learn a few things.

http://dronefortheholidaysboston.com/
results.name: Drone For The Holidays

Beginner's Meditation RETREAT-  

Pre-registration is filled.

Walk-ins will be taken if room permits.

SATURDAY | JANUARY 9th 


10:00am - 1:00pm

Why meditate? 

Buddha taught that meditation is the main cause of inner peace, and inner peace is the real cause of happiness. So, learning to meditate is the best way to overcome stress and to keep a positive, relaxed attitude throughout life’s ups and downs.

By following these practical, down-to-earth instructions, anyone can learn to meditate. Buddha taught meditation techniques that everybody can practice—no matter who you are or who you’ve been—so that everyone can experience a happy and meaningful life—no matter where you are or who you’re with!

This 2-session retreat will consist of guided meditations, teachings, and time for questions. No previous meditation experience is necessary. Everyone is welcome!

Cost | $25  / $15 students & seniors.   Free for Patrons!

Pre-registration is filled.

Walk-ins will be taken if room permits.

Location | 179 Green Street – Boston, Jamaica Plain, MA 02130  

meditationINboston.org

results.description:
Reiki 1 is focused on helping you heal yourself, but you will also learn how to offer Reiki to family and friends and use it in every day situations. This is a place to start on your Reiki journey. No previous experience is necessary and this is a great class to take even if you just want to learn more about meditation, mindfulness, and energy healing.

https://youtu.be/3NViTcR1YAE

This class is taught over four weekly classes. Each class is 90 minutes long.

In Reiki 1 class

• You will gain ability to practice Reiki on yourself and others

• Learn history of Reiki

• Learn about theoretical and practical applications of energy healing

• Practice simple meditative techniques

• Workbook binder with Reiki I materials to take home is included

• Journal is provided

Cost: $128

Olga Kaminsky is a Reiki Master Teacher who made a jump from a corporate high-tech to a world of alternative healing shortly after her Reiki Master training. First experiencing energy flow during a yoga class, Olga started on her Reiki journey in 2005. She has been offering Reiki, yoga, and other healing modalities in a professional setting since 2009. Equally comfortable talking about spirit or mundane, Olga's gift is to make heart-based living accessible to anyone. Whether you have a highly logical mindset or you are a creative type, you would benefit from learning Reiki and letting love and compassion into your life!

Olga holds Reiki Master Teacher level certifications in both Usui and Komyo Reiki Kai (Western and Eastern styles).
results.name: Reiki 1 Class

results.description:
(a set of 6 Saturday classes)


Always wanted to learn how they really fought in the middle ages? Forget any ideas about crude battering on armour; the successful warrior strikes to the gaps and the openings of his or her opponent's attacks, and supplements this with disarms, throws, and other techniques which secure the advantage over larger or stronger attackers.

Around the year 1400, Fiore dei Liberi trained medieval knights and squires, and authored multiple books of medieval combat, some of which have survived to the present day. His method, L'Arte d'Armizare (the Art of Bearing Arms), shows an integrated and cross-referenced system of sword, dagger, grappling, spear & lance, pollaxe and other weapons on foot and on horseback, with and without armour, and easily dispels any illusions that medieval combat was about unskilled strength.

Our beginners' course is six linked classes that give the basic techniques and vocabulary of L'Arte, and enables men and women to begin regular unarmoured training and learning.  No prior training needed; all class equipment is provided.

So, come join the scholars and combatants of our company!

(The price shown is for the set of all six classes (Jan 9, 16, 23, 30, Feb 6 and 13) and membership and registration.  Classes are not offered separately.  We'll send an email with some class materials before the first session.)

results.description:
BOOK:

In the Convent of Little Flowers: Stories by Indu Sundaresan

Only 8 copies in the Minuteman Library System.

DESCRIPTION:

Now in paperback, internationally bestselling author Indu Sundaresan presents a poignant collection of contemporary short stories about the challenges and consequences faced by women in Indian life today.
Like Jhumpa Lahiri’s Interpreter of Maladies, Indu Sundaresan’s In the Convent of Little Flowers gives readers an eloquent and illuminating collection of stories about contemporary Indian life, exploring the cutting-edge issues that surround the clash between ancient tradition and modernity. In the collection’s title story, a young woman adopted by an American family in Seattle receives a letter from Sister Mary Theresa, a nun at the Convent of Little Flowers in Chennai, where she stayed as a child. Unbeknownst to the Indian woman, the nun is her biological mother’s sister. In another story, the grandmother of an Indian journalist begs her grandson to intervene and stop a young widow from being burned alive. And when a teenaged daughter bears a child out of wedlock, her entire family is thrown into turmoil. With their lush prose, vividly rendered settings, and complex characters, these and the other stories in this elegant collection bring readers into the experience of Indian women at home and abroad, where modernity offers them lives their grandmothers could never dream of, while at the same time taking away parts of their history. With a delicate touch, Indu Sundaresan weaves the pieces of the conflict together, presenting a nuanced and unforgettable tapestry.

results.description:
"Your first 10,000 photos are your worst."  Henri Cartier-Bresson   Time to take the leap into the new year and turn off  auto. If you have already started using other settings, this class will help make sense of the choices so you know what to do in different shooting situations more quickly. By the end of the workshop you will have more confidence and skill in understanding how to use your camera.

Discover how to make the most of your camera.

This is the first of a series of 4 classes I will offer on understanding how to you your camera more fully. There will be one class each month delving into the technical capabilities of your camera so you can take better pictures. But I PROMISE TO MAKE IT FUN FUN FUN.  Yes eventually you can figure it all out by yourself, but in person instruction is more efficient and effective.

We all want to take photos that are in focus and properly exposed. I just happen to think it can be fun, exciting and interesting to discover how to do this. Once you go off auto, you will never want to go back. Understanding the relationship between shutter speed, aperture setting, and ISO is all you need to accomplish this.


Learn how to choose the best aperture setting for depth of field.

Image A has the correct Aperture Setting for achieving the interesting blurred background and proper lighting. Image B Aperture Setting is not as good because it did not blur the background enough to make the subject stand out. 

I will lead you step by step making it fun, simple and easy. This is not just theory, it is hands on. So after I introduce a concept, you will practice it by doing the steps and taking some photos. Then we will review what you have done so you can see what to do to modify the camera setting.

Learn how to choose the proper shutter speed to catch the action.

Image A does not have the correct Shutter Speed to catch the action. Image B has the correct shutter speed so the subject is in focus.

We will work in small groups so you will be with others who have the same type of camera you have. This way you can help each other learn. 

What you will learn:

• How to find your way around your camera menu.

• How to choose the right settings for the three most common scenes.

• How to understand the relationship between shutter speed, depth of field, and ISO. (sensitivity) so you can make the right choices for camera settings.

This is a non technical group so I will keep the jargon to a minimum and go slow. 

Learn how to choose the proper ISO (sensitivity) for low light situations.

This workshop is for you if:

• You have tried using aperture or shutter priority but have not been happy with the results.

• You have a new camera and want to learn your way around the settings.

• You have tried to learn by reading the manual or from You Tube but are still not really clear about what to do when you get out in the real world.

• You would like to have FUN  while learning new skills with other like minded people. 


We will meet at my art studio at the Boston Center for the Arts where we can look at some sample images, study our settings and get ready to go out and shoot in the South End weather permitting.  

You will need to bring your camera manual.

This class would also be a great gift for someone you know and would like encourage to start taking better photos. YOU can purchase the class as a gift for yourself or for them. Just send me a note with the participants name and I will add them to the class list. They do not need to be a member of our group. 

I am going to limit the size of this class to 10 so if you are interested, please RSVP right away to make sure you have a spot. 

Happy New Year!

Suzanne

Calling all actors, writers, and crew for JANUARY 9TH from 2:00 - 4:00 p.m. Are you interested in an innovative new film contest? The New England chapter of Women in Film and Video and Harvard Square Script Writers are sponsoring a film festival that challenges filmmakers to tell the stories least often heard in the industry. Stretch your imagination and win big at the Different Faces, Different Voices film festival in Boston with two-days of screenings in June.

You can learn all about this upcoming contest at the Women in Film and Video meetup this coming Saturday, January 9th at the University Lutheran Church at 66 Winthrop St. in Cambridge from 2:00 – 4:00 p.m.

Sign-ups for the contest begin on February 14th and crews will have one-month from a start date of April 1st to produce an original short, following the guidelines of the challenge. This year’s contest focuses on Flicks4Chicks and it will be a requirement that at least one member of the creative team – director; writer; producer; editor; dp must be female; the film is also required to feature a main female character. This Saturday’s meetup is FREE and you’ll learn about Women in Film and Video, have an opportunity to join the organization for a big contest discount, meet other people in the industry, and enjoy light refreshments. Beverages will be available for purchase. Don’t miss getting in on the ground floor of this event!

results.description:
All active members and those considering membership are invited to a Start-Of-The-Year Meetup at the beautiful University Lutheran Church Alumni Room in the heart of Harvard Square on Saturday, January 9th from 2:00 - 4:00 p.m.

Learn about the organization, meet other men and women in the industry, explore opportunities for joining the board, during our 2016 Board Nomination and Election period.   Plus, get a first look at our upcoming film contest Flicks4Chicks.  Snacks will be served and beverages will be available for purchase.  The Church is located at 66 Winthrop Street.  It is less than 2 blocks from the Harvard Square T Stop on the Red Line.

WIFVNE is currently holding open nominations for members to be placed on the ballot for our 2016 Board Election.  The nomination period runs until January 15th.  The election will take place from January 16th-18th, and election results will be announced on January 19th.  Only active members may participate in the election process.  We have recently changed our Bylaws to allow Student level members to vote and to be nominated to serve on the WIFVNE Board.  Read more about WIFVNE Board service HERE!  If you're not a WIFVNE member yet - JOIN HERE!

The Flicks4Chicks contest, which will open for sign-ups on February 14th, will challenge teams of filmmakers to create a unique short (ten minutes or less in length) featuring a female as a major character.

The competition hopes to inspire original fictional stories that delve into the realities of a wide variety of women and girls (of differing races, ethnicities and ages) as they embrace their own destinies, taking charge of their lives as fully realized human beings, and not simply as Hollywood caricatures or sidelined shadows.

Each team will be given a set of situations to choose from and will have a period of one month from the contest start date of April 1st to complete and submit their project. Active members of any WIF chapter will have $25.00 off the submission fee of $100.00.

Crew may come from anywhere in the world but must complete their film in English (or with English subtitles) and must have a female in at least one of the following creative roles: producer, director, director of photography, writer, editor.

The screenings/festival will be held in Cambridge in late June with major awards and prizes offered.

To learn more, plan to attend the Meetup and connect with potential collaborators.

results.description:
CHECK IN AT 2:30, put your backpacks in the lockers, get your tickets, and Meet & Greet then at 2:45 we're OFF!   
   
For the 8th time, at this popular & incredible gem of a Museum meetup location. We meet just inside the main entrance & head (this time) to the elevators area by the stairs to the 2nd floor. Then we go into the Tobey Gallery right there & pass through to the Fancy Silverware exhibition. We continue on past the masterpieces portraying George Washington and Napoleon, to the painting called Feigned Flight (image below-- the man in the painting who is pursuing her is not in this image which defines it), Ingres' Studies for the Martyrdom, Moreau's Jacob and the Angel (image below), The incredible Call to Arms mini study sculpture by Rodin, Dante Rossetti, & Burne-Jones's works.  And don't forget the room for the great 16th cent. sculptor Bernini.
   
NOTE-- hosts will not linger at some of the galleries but PASS RIGHT THROUGH  others because there will be MUCH MORE to see after this.  So GO! stay with the company. This is a meetup enjoy the company; if you want to come earlier to linger at your fav places do that then.  

At 4 PM regroup at the elevators and head back downstairs to the Surrealist Art (follow the hosts) --note the weird sculpture Detroit Queen. Loop through there and get to the Picassos and the last room back towards the entrance including the Bathers by Renoir --then meet us again back at the open area cafeteria. 

If you do lose us or get tired, look for others in the meetup at the cafeteria back on the first floor, where we gather again and leave AT 4:45 to Felipe's in Harvard Square. That is a 15 minute walk through Harvard Yard.   
   
ADMISSION free for Cambridge residents with a drivers license. Otherwise it's $15. Backpacks not allowed. You can store them in lockers across from the admissions area, alternately there is another locker area down one floor from there.

http://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-7he8jlARtuM/VJmDezIHhRI/AAAAAAAEzwg/v9Rn311tEa8/s288/DSC00954.JPG
results.how_to_find_us: Just inside the main entrance at 2:30

  FOLLOWING THIS WE HEAD ACROSS HARVARD YARD TO FELIPE'S FOR REFRESHMENTS IN HARVARD SQUARE AT 4 :45 short walk across Harvard Yard about 15 mins. 
    
For the 8th time, at this popular & incredible gem of a Museum meetup location. results.description:
Twelve significant photographs in any one year is a good crop. Ansel Adams

Greetings Photographers!  This virtual challenge starts NOW and ends Jan. 9th. 

It has been a FABULOUS YEAR. Thank you for participating in soooooo many workshops. Since starting this group I have offered 138 workshops covering topics from macro photography, urban landscapes, composition, color, flowers, blue hour, and on and on. I have many new topics planned for next year based on your requests and look forward to sharing that content with you. 

But before we rush into the next year, I thought it would be fun to take a look at our year in review. I would love to see some of the photos you are most proud of so hope you will participate in this virtual challenge and post your favorite 5. 

It is an excellent practice in looking over your work and selecting the images that stand out. If you have been an active member you know that learning to critique is one of the fastest ways to become a better photographer.

The last photo class of 2015 Boston Night Lights 

What is a virtual challenge?

This is a type of meetup I learned about while in Amsterdam last year. The virtual challenge means there is no physical meetup. You  participate by posting your photos here on our meetup page. This is a great way to keep building skills while I am out of town like right now. 

Challenge deadline: January 9th 3:00pm 

Blue Hour Workshop 

 Five Fab Photos from 2015. Your challenge is to review your photos from the past year and select your favorite 5. 

Urban Landscape Seeing color

These can be photos you have taken during one of our workshops and if so please identify the class in your title. If not from a class perhaps they highlight something you learned this year. You can add a comment about a key discovery you made and how it is illustrated in your photo. 

Rockport Field Trip 

New members to the group are more than welcome to participate. This is a great way to get constructive feedback on your photos. Take some time to not only post your photos but to offer constructive feedback or point out what you like most about a photo. This helps us all learn from each other.


How to post:

RSVP yes to participate.

Simply click on the word photo in the menu bar. Then it will ask you to upload images. They will automatically go into the album setup for this Virtual challenge.

You can also vote for your favorite 5 photo posted by other photographers. To do this just type +A  in the comment section for the photos you just love. This will help cultivate your eye and learn what you love. 


Flower Power Workshop 

Challenge deadline: January 9th 3:00pm I can't wait to see your 5 favorite photos and comments. Thank you for a FABULOUS YEAR  and welcome to all our new members! I hope you will join us in person very soon now that you have joined the group. 

Another challenge you can help me with is to grow our group. I would love to have 2000 members by Jan. 15st  If you know some one who loves photography please personally invite them to join our meetup group right now.

Just copy and share the link to this page with one person and we will hit 2000 no problem. I really appreciate your support and enthusiasm. 

Looking forward to seeing  you mid January for our first workshop of 2015. Suzanne.


Suzanne

We will practice together, play and study theory.

Usually we get quite a few beginners, so if you are just starting don't be shy, you definitely can join us. If you have been playing for some time I am sure you will find a few helpful ideas as well. If the level will be very different then we might divide it to two groups eventually.

Half of the class time is dedicated to a consecutive curriculum. We try to choose themes that are relevant to everybody in the class. We might talk about some aspects of technique, or reading, or theory etc. The other half of the class time we usually help students with their individual issues and questions.

We see this class as a supportive and motivational environment for your self-teaching process. There are two experienced guitar teachers (Anastasiya Dumma and David Lee), both Berklee grads, who are ready to answer all your questions and suggest new things to practice!

This is PAY-WHAT-YOU-WANT class. We kindly ask you to support your teachers and Westland Guitars that provided the space. Online donations feel a bit inconvenient (sorry), so you can contribute when you come to the class.

results.description:
HFA members are allowed to bring one guest to this private FREE screening party. The Films are DESTRY RIDES AGAIN (1939, with James Stewart and Marlene Dietrich) at 7, followed by a reception, then the last
Dean Martin/Jerry Lewis pairing in HOLLYWOOD OR BUST (1956) at 9:15.

Since this is a double feature with a reception in between, we won't have the usual post-movie outing, but we can mingle and chat at the reception. Please respond if you are interested, although we'll need an equal number of members and non members for all non-members to get in. Unless of course you call the HFA and become a member in advance OR enroll as a member at the event! I've really enjoyed my membership at the HFA this past year.

Check out the HFA site if you are interested in becoming a member: http://hcl.harvard.edu/hfa/general_info.html#membership.

For those that rsvp to this meetup, I'll send an email with specific logistics.
results.name: Members Night at Harvard Film Archive - FREE film screenings of classic films

results.description:
Zinfandel truly is “America’s Wine Grape”; it has a unique history, many varied styles and has thrived the best here in California. We’ll do 3 flights of 4; first trying some of Zinfandels relative wines- Primitivo from Italy, Plavic Mali and Crjlenak both from the Croatian region along side a classic california ZIN. Then we’ll move on to California where we’ll try Zins from various regions. There will plenty more to enjoy after the official flights if you're up for it! Perhaps you’ll become a ZINfanatic like me!

Thomas will be providing all of the wines and food. He’ll be putting together a “California” inspired menu to go with our delicious zin selection. Think guacamole, roasted and braised meats, fresh creative veggie dishes…..

Limit 16.  The waitlist will disappear one week before event.  After that, if a spot opens an email will be sent to the entire group and whoever responds first will get the spot.


HOW TO PAY:  Preferred method is PayPal.  Thomas's PayPal email is: [masked].  If you don't have a PayPal account, it's very quick and easy to set up.  You don't have to fill in your bank account information (though they want you to).  You can just use a credit card.

* If you do not pay when you RSVP you will be moved to the wait list until payment is received.
results.name: Forgive me for I have ZINned!

results.description: I am happy to announce that Cathy Stacy and Don Goldman are now the facilitators of this circle. We are located at the beautiful studio of Yoga Mandala in Winchester, 750 Main Street, second floor. There is a parking lot. Drummers, dancers, didgers of all levels all welcome for this friendly and welcoming drum circle. A $5 donation is greatly appreciated. results.description:
My New Years resolution is to not only work hard, but play harder!  I've been out of the loop, with Real Estate being busy, and it's time for Susan time.

If anyone would like to join me Saturday night, Wildfire, one of my fave groups is playing at TPS and it would be awesome to celebrate my 49th birthday again.  (It's really the 14th, but I figured noone would want to go out in the middle of the week)

I thought 7:30 was a good time to "meet and greet" have a bite to eat and then boogie it off, to some good tunes.  Wildfire gets the crowd going and I really need a night out.  This isn't all about me...winter can be boring and cold, and make you want to stay indoors by the fire, but I figured if I post it, I have to go.  LOL.

the place is going to be packed, I heard.  I have a reservation for only 10, but anyone can have my seat after the band comes on at 9pm, because you'll find me on the dance floor.

the following people have said they are coming for dinner and are accounted for. If your not on the list, it's because you didn't answer the question about dinner when you wrote back yes on your reply.

I just heard the place is going to be packed, and they will not make any more reservations...whew.  I have reservations for Sue and Deb, Kathy and Steve, John and Kathy, Martha and Laurie, Allyson and Ken.  I will need to make name cards.  If you are not named, it's because first, I couldn't get any bigger a table, so if you can find another table that would be great, or join us for dancing after 9pm when Wildfire starts whooping it up. If you are named and you are not comiing, please let me know asap, as someone wants to take your place. 

Thanks SUZ


Happy New Year everyone...wishing you a happy and healthy New Year ahead.
results.how_to_find_us: Ask for Susan's birthday not meet up, table to the left of the band
results.name: Celebrate my birthday with me, anyone?r

results.description:
The Mandorla Music Series presents live jazz and related music in intimate spaces in Union Square, Somerville. This Saturday night, come hear a pair of duos featuring two of the area's finest saxophonists at Third Life Studio, 33 Union Square, Somerville. Russ Gershon will team up with drummer Phil Neighbors, and Charlie Kohlhase with bassist Aaron Darrell. Both work primarily in acclaimed larger ensembles - don't miss this unique opportunity to hear each of them in the intimate musical space of a duo.

Russ says, "This format takes me back to my teenage years of hearing music in the legendary jazz lofts of New York, when you could hear giants like Lester Bowie, Julius Hemphill and Arthur Blythe play solo or duo in intimate spaces. It's an inspiring creative challenge." Expect to hear compelling original music and spirited takes on compositions by Mahmoud Ahmed, Julius Hemphill, James Brown, Sun Ra and others...and the word is that the evening will end with a quartet finale. Wow. This will be a very special night.  Space is limited so advance tix are recommended.  $12 in advance / $15 at the door. Tix at <a>www.mandorlamusic.net.</a>

Note that Third Life is a small storefront healing & performing arts studio, not a bar or restaurant. There will likely be soft drinks and nibbles available for donation at the venue, but please plan to come early and stay late to eat & drink at one of Union Square's many fine bars & restaurants.
results.name: live jazz in Union Square, Somervile

HERE WE GO!

It was great to see everyone out this past Sunday at Cityside for what ended up being a crazy finish to the 2015 regular season. It wasn't pretty, but the Steelers snuck into the postseason for a record 29th time. The black and gold are scheduled to suit up Saturday night in Cincy in search of the team's first playoff win since clear back in 2010. 

As always, we'll be upstairs at Cityside for Boston's official Steelers game-watch party. Please RSVP if you plan on coming out so we have an idea of the crowd size. The tentative plan is to turn over all the upstairs tables immediately following the conclusion of the early game. Please be patient as the staff works to clear the area for our group.  


For those that asked about koozies, we'll be sure to have a bunch on hand this weekend ($1 each). 

See yinz Saturday!

results.description:
Meet to paint the model for a five week pose- Members (those paying the $25 monthly membership fee) may reserve a spot for $75, non-members for $90.    Three hours each Sunday morning, 9:30-12:30.  You can come individual days by paying $15 (members) or $25 (non-members) for a single drop-in, but please consider paying for the full amount and committing to come!  It will help us to keep these long sessions going, and even if you pay for the whole session and don't come to all of them (often happens), you're getting a pretty square deal.  If you would like to pay online please do so at


http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html 

PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.  

----- IF THE CAPACITY REACHES 12, whether or not that number shows up on the RSVP list, we may have to close the session to further drop-ins to preserve breathing space for those who reserved ahead. ------

 Please consider that for $75 or $90 (non-member) you can reserve ahead for the whole month, which helps us stay open for business.  If you want to drop in, you can RSVP and pay online- simply change the amount of the payment at the payment stage to reflect the drop-in rate above.
results.how_to_find_us: corner of Vernon and Central streets
results.name: Sunday painting

results.description:
Registration is open for Boston's January AGA-rated 2016 go tournament! To register: Email [masked] with your playing strength and your AGA number if you know it. Players who pre-register get a $5 discount on the entry fee and also help speed up the paperwork so we can get to the games faster!

Important Details:
Tournament is in four rounds of games, Japanese rules.
Main time is 45 minutes with a Canadian overtime period of 25 moves per 5 minutes.
Komi of 7.5 in even games, komi of .5 in handicapped games.
AGA rated tournament, so you will need an up-to-date membership with them.
Entry fee is $20 for MGA members and $25 for non-members, with a $5 discount for pre-registrants.
Registration starts at 9:45 and play will begin at 10:30.
Street parking in this neighborhood is free on Sundays.

1st Prize: $50
2nd Prize: $30
3rd Prize: $20

Email James if you have any questions, good luck to everyone on their various games!

results.description:
Doors for the event open at 10:00 AM for coffee and conversation, with the program starting at 10:30. We hope to see you there!


Featured Speaker: Helen Stringer, M.S.- executive director of KC Oasis

Community Moment: J. Michael Spencer

Musical Guest: Amanda McCarthy


About our featured speaker:

Shortly after obtaining a bachelor’s degree in pastoral studies, Helen Stringer came to realize she could no longer support any religious ideologies. She redirected her passion for community and helping others by working as a center director and counselor for a local nonprofit that assists young families in crisis. Simultaneously, she completed her master’s degree in human services with a graduate certificate in professional counseling.

Now, Helen is bringing her training and passion for community to Oasis with a desire to bring together secular individuals and families who don’t fit in church. In early 2014, she founded and now serves as the executive director of Kansas City Oasis, a secular alternative to faith-based community. She also co-founded and serves as the president of the Oasis Network, the affiliate organization that helps to launch and support Oasis communities around the country.

"The Rationalist's Delusion- An Introduction to Moral Psychology"

Based on Johnathan Haidt's book "The Righteous Mind: Why Good People Are Divided by Politics and Religion", Helen Stringer will share some of the most recent research in moral psychology and help the audience rethink just how reasonable they really are.

=========================================

Oasis meets in the Teen Center at the YMCA. To find the room, enter through the lower entrance (on Dartmouth Street, by the swimming pool), and follow Oasis signs from the front lobby to the Teen Center on the second floor. (Note: the stairwell to the Teen Center is NOT the stairwell in the front lobby. That is Stairwell A. The Teen Center is located at Stairwell B, next to the Yoga Studio. Oasis volunteers will be available to help provide assistance, and signage will be posted.

=========================================

Greater Boston Oasis is a secular community dedicated to providing for the human need for social and intellectual community, for those people who may not want or be able to have those needs met in a church or other faith-based community. 

Our Core Values are:

People are more important than beliefs

Reality is known through reason

Meaning comes from making a difference

Human hands solve human problems

Be accepting, and be accepted


Atheist or agnostic, freethinker or skeptic, deist or theist, all those with whom those values resonate are welcome to celebrate the human experience.
results.how_to_find_us: Follow signs from the entrance to the Teen Center room. Use the Dartmouth Street entrance, and head to Stairwell B. Teen Center is on the 2nd floor.

results.description:
Think of this as a creative mini-retreat. It's designed primarily for writers—of all experience levels, working in any genre. However, those working in art journals are welcome to attend as well.


WHAT WE'LL DO: We'll start at 12:15 sharp with a few easy creativity prompts, if there's interest. Beginning at 1 p.m  sharp., we'll just write, write, write (or create, create, create). 

Although we'll be in the same large room, we'll be writing in companionable silence, talking only during breaks. If you'd like to have a conversation with someone, you're welcome to step outside.

No one will critique your work—or read or see it—unless you choose to share it, probably at the end of the day. If there's interest, we can go out for dinner after the session.


AMENITIES: Located about 3.5 miles south of South Shore Plaza in a residential neighborhood, the Braintree Community Arts Center is a converted two-story house that we'll have entirely to ourselves for the day. It's bright, pleasant, and equipped with tables, chairs, restrooms, a coffeemaker, a fridge, a microwave, free parking, and Wi-Fi. Stores and restaurants are nearby. I will provide a few books for inspiration, and an extension cord and power strip for power.

WHAT TO BRING: Yourself, your writing projects and writing implements (computer or  writing notebook and pen, or journal). Bring your own beverage. Feel free to bring a snack to share—but that’s entirely optional.

COST: $10 (cash or check), regardless of how long you stay.


HOW TO SIGN UP: Reserve a place by RSVP-ing "yes" using Meetup's RSVP function.


CANCELLATIONS: In the unlikely event that we need to cancel—or even if we're just getting a late start—we'll post a message on the Web site and e-mail everyone who's RSVP'd "yes."

REMINDER ABOUT ABOUT RSVPs: Your RSVP is a reservation, and we're trusting that you'll honor it. If you can't make it, please change your RSVP from "yes" to "no" at least 24 hours in advance. If you cancel with less than 24 hours notice, or if you RSVP "yes" and then don't show up, you'll be asked to pay the fee anyway to help cover our costs for the day.


Looking forward to seeing you!

results.description:
The MFA is showing films written by Graham Greene, including the classic The Third Man. Hear the famous zither score and see Orson Welles deliver the famous cuckoo clock speech!

From the MFA website:
Writer Holly Martins arrives in Vienna at the invitation of his old college friend, Harry Lime – only to find that Harry has been killed in a suspicious car accident. With the help of Lime’s former girlfriend, Martins endeavors to piece together the details of his friend’s death by visiting Lime’s old haunts in the darkest corners of post-war Vienna.

Considered one of the greatest films of all time, this morbid thriller was adapted from a novella Greene wrote specifically to serve as “raw material” for the film. It illustrates a moral struggle between two very different characters: a depressed alcoholic of good moral fiber, and a charming sociopath who views humanity through a scientific lens. These two opposing philosophies may echo a moral conflict taking place in Greene’s own mind.
results.name: The Third Man at the MFA

results.description:
Want to learn Vietnamese? The Vietnamese class for adults will be on Sundays from 12:30pm to 2:30pm at VietAID Center, 42 Charles Street, Dorchester, second floor. This is the Charles St in Dorchester, near Fields Corner T Stop on the Red Line, not Charles St, Boston. There is also a small parking lot.

This school year has 3 trimesters of about 10 weeks each (not including holiday weekends). This is the 2nd trimester. Students can sign up for 1, 2, or hopefully all 3. Fee for each trimester is $60 and you pay as you go for the trimester(s) that you take. The fee helps pay for space rental, books, printings, snacks, and other miscellaneous items that will be purchased for the class. The teacher is southern Vietnamese but he will teach in the northern dialect. The southern pronounce certain letters (d, g, v) the same, which makes it more difficult to learn to read.

There is no homework and no tests, only practice and recitation.

Trimester 2
01/10/16 1 - B1:L9, Grammar 4, Numbers
01/17/16 2 - Dialogs with Numbers
01/24/16 3 - Sing a Song (prepare for Tet Party)
01/31/16 4 - Tết Party (join other classes at 10am)
02/07/16 5 - TẾT - no class
02/14/16 6 - WINTER BREAK- no class
02/21/16 7 - Grammar 5, Dialogs with Money
02/28/16 8 - B1:L10. Grammar 6, Time
03/06/16 9 - Dialogs with Time
03/13/16 10 - Review & Catchup
03/20/16 11 - TEST, Class Party
results.name: Vietnamese Language Class for Adults - 2nd Trimester

Please join us for a pleasant afternoon of competitive party bridge.

Bertucci's has its own parking lot, a welcoming atmosphere, and hearty food (including all-you-can-eat salads and soups).

Please sign up by Saturday afternoon, the day before the game. If at least 5 players have not registered by then, the game will have to be cancelled for that week.

You must know Contract Bridge rules and basic bidding to play. No formal training will be offered, but this is a social, casual event, and bidding advice and meanings will be openly discussed at any player's request.

ACBL Yellow Card is our group-standard bidding system; a novice should please take time to study all basic openings and responses shown above, plus standard Jacoby Transfer and Stayman responses to NT openings. We will expect a verbal alert on deviations an expert may make to these most-common conventions.

results.description:
Because there are so many people on the wait list for the Saturday class, I have decided to offer it again on Sunday. I hope this fits with your schedule and you can join us as we focus on turning off Auto! Suzanne

"Your first 10,000 photos are your worst."  Henri Cartier-Bresson   Time to take the leap into the new year and turn off  auto. If you have already started using other settings, this class will help make sense of the choices so you know what to do in different shooting situations more quickly. By the end of the workshop you will have more confidence and skill in understanding how to use your camera.

Discover how to make the most of your camera.

This is the first of a series of 4 classes I will offer on understanding how to you your camera more fully. There will be one class each month delving into the technical capabilities of your camera so you can take better pictures. But I PROMISE TO MAKE IT FUN FUN FUN.  Yes eventually you can figure it all out by yourself, but in person instruction is more efficient and effective.

We all want to take photos that are in focus and properly exposed. I just happen to think it can be fun, exciting and interesting to discover how to do this. Once you go off auto, you will never want to go back. Understanding the relationship between shutter speed, aperture setting, and ISO is all you need to accomplish this.


Learn how to choose the best aperture setting for depth of field.

Image A has the correct Aperture Setting for achieving the interesting blurred background and proper lighting. Image B Aperture Setting is not as good because it did not blur the background enough to make the subject stand out. 

I will lead you step by step making it fun, simple and easy. This is not just theory, it is hands on. So after I introduce a concept, you will practice it by doing the steps and taking some photos. Then we will review what you have done so you can see what to do to modify the camera setting.

Learn how to choose the proper shutter speed to catch the action.

Image A does not have the correct Shutter Speed to catch the action. Image B has the correct shutter speed so the subject is in focus.

We will work in small groups so you will be with others who have the same type of camera you have. This way you can help each other learn. 

What you will learn:

• How to find your way around your camera menu.

• How to choose the right settings for the three most common scenes.

• How to understand the relationship between shutter speed, depth of field, and ISO. (sensitivity) so you can make the right choices for camera settings.

This is a non technical group so I will keep the jargon to a minimum and go slow. 

Learn how to choose the proper ISO (sensitivity) for low light situations.

This workshop is for you if:

• You have tried using aperture or shutter priority but have not been happy with the results.

• You have a new camera and want to learn your way around the settings.

• You have tried to learn by reading the manual or from You Tube but are still not really clear about what to do when you get out in the real world.

• You would like to have FUN  while learning new skills with other like minded people. 


We will meet at my art studio at the Boston Center for the Arts where we can look at some sample images, study our settings and get ready to go out and shoot in the South End weather permitting.  

You will need to bring your camera manual.

This class would also be a great gift for someone you know and would like encourage to start taking better photos. YOU can purchase the class as a gift for yourself or for them. Just send me a note with the participants name and I will add them to the class list. They do not need to be a member of our group. 

I am going to limit the size of this class to 10 so if you are interested, please RSVP right away to make sure you have a spot. 

Happy New Year!

Suzanne

From Sarah M:

May the force be with Ryan!

If you don't already know, I am a nanny. One of my former charges was recently diagnosed with Medulloblastoma, a brain tumor. The family is in Austin, TX and with me being in Boston, I feel a little helpless. Well that's were you come in, I need knitters. I am making Ryan a Star Wars blanket and in order to get it done quickly I am planning a knit a thon. We will be getting together on Sunday January 10th to knock out a whole blanket in one afternoon (hopefully)! Below will be a link to the families blog. If you cannot make the knitting event and would like to donate, the family has a go fund me page and the link is on the blog. I will also be collecting donations on Mondays at knitwits and during our Sunday knit a thon! Thank you for your support and hope to see everyone on the 10th! For those of you planning to knit the pattern calls for intarsia color work done flat, (it's not as hard as it seems). I will include a video of intarsia knitting, please review and become familiar with the technique. Etten Family blog:
http://maytheforcebewithryan.com/

Intarsia Video:
https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=gK07PBQMTE8

Blanket Pattern:
http://www.ravelry.com/patterns/library/star-wars-craft-charts

We will be using knit picks wool of the Andes worsted, so I'm thinking size 7 or 8 straight needles. I will post gauge recommendations soon!
results.name: May The Force Be With Ryan

results.description:
Hi All,

Continuing with our indoor series, let's check out the Boston Athenaeum this Sunday!

The Boston Athenaeum, founded in 1807, is one of the oldest independent libraries in the US, and serves to preserve the book collection and landmark building. It holds a large collection of books in circulation as well as rare books and art. The architect of 10 1/2 Beacon St. was Edward Clarke Cabot, an artist and dilettante.  His design, based on the needs of the library, allowed more space on all floors above the basement level. The neo-Palladian façade of "Patterson sandstone" was unique in Boston and remains so today.

The Athanaeum is a pen/pencil only facility, although colored pencils are allowed. In addition, the library requires all visitors to store their bags at the entrance in complimentary lockers. Keys are provided for the lockers. Bags must be smaller than 11x15 inches, so keep your art supplies in small bags to take into the Athanaeum. More information can be found here:

https://www.bostonathenaeum.org/


Hope to see you this Sunday!


-Miriam

P.S. Among their curiosities curated at the Athanaeum is a book bound in human skin. The book is the 1837 memoirs of a highwayman, bank robber, and "sneak thief" James Allen, who requested his ill deeds be bound in his skin because he declared himself to be the "'master of his own skin." Creepy, no?
results.how_to_find_us: Let's meet in the entrance of the Athenaeum. I will have a blue messenger back with green flowers.
results.name: Let's Sketch! The Boston Atheneaum

results.description:
Does the world still have the same meaning and sense of sacredness in a secular world? Literature and art as social reflection are probably the most powerful tools mankind has utilized to understand who we are, what we are, and where we may be going. What better time to consider how to live life as we move to a New Year and as we encounter so much strife and loss in the world?

Join us for a discussion with Dr. Erik Gregory, PhD, LMHC.
results.name: Erik Gregory: Hello from the Outside: Secular Art, Adele & New Year's Resolution

results.description:
***This meetup is restricted to people who have attended at least one discussion of the Knapsack meetup group in the last six months. (Most of our meetups count.)***

Each session includes time to: connect with each other, silently reflect and write about our anti-racism work, report on how we're doing regarding our anti-racism work, and receive input and feedback.  We usually do the reporting and input/feedback in small groups of 3-4 people.  If you can't stay as late as 4:30, please go ahead and RSVP, just let us know your limitations.

Remember to bring your notebook, if you have one!  (We'll have a few extra for anyone who hasn't come to an accountability/support session before.) Also, feel free to bring any writings or objects you want to share as part of your anti-racism thinking and work.

We generally schedule one accountability/support session each month. If you are unable to attend and want to be part of accountability, we will consider scheduling an additional session for the month, or choosing a time that works for you in the next month.


For more about our thoughts on these sessions, see "Open discussion to consider monthly accountability sessions."  Note: even if you don't claim to be doing anti-racism work, you can come to the session and see what it is about, as well as consider your own role.  The requirement still applies: you must have attended one of our discussion meetups within the last six months.


This is also a place where you can learn about and find an accountabilibuddy. 

Accessibility Information: Community Change, Inc. is wheelchair accessible with the following limitations.  The door to the building is heavy and does not have a button to open it. The elevator doors are slightly more than 30 inches wide.  The fourth floor bathrooms are not wheelchair accessible, but the first floor bathroom is.  Please let us know your needs so we can help make the event accessible for you.

results.description:
POTLUCK AND DISCUSSION

We've all heard the hype, hope and happenstance emanating from the recent COP21 climate negotiations in Paris.  Now you can hear the inside story first hand from two of our friends who were there, both experts in their respective fields and popular speakers at our conferences. 

Tom Goreau is a biogeophysicist and reef restoration expert with experience in climate and land management going back to before the climate negotiations began in 1992.  Judy Schwartz is a journalist whose ground-breaking book, Cows Save the Planet, opened up wide-ranging discussion on eco-restoration, which presents the most effective and promising approaches to addressing the climate dilemma.

We'll start with a half-hour light potluck (please bring a dish to share), then continue at 2:30 with presentations from Judy and Tom with plenty of opportunity for questions and discussion.

We're a small non-profit so a $10 donation is requested, but no one will be turned away based on ability to pay.

Helen Snively's house is about halfway between Central Square and Inman Square. Take the MBTA red line to Central Square, exit the station walking down Massachusetts Avenue in the direction of Harvard Square (away from Boston). Walk five blocks and make a right on Lee Street, then walk two blocks past Harvard Street and Broadway. Cross Broadway onto Fayette Street (which will be in front of you), walk down Fayette and make your first left onto Fayette Park (a private way). Helen's house is at One Fayette Park, immediately past the first driveway on the right.  It's a green 4-family. Come up on the first porch and look for a no. 1 on the door.  If you have questions please post to this Meetup,  or call Helen at[masked]-1326.
results.name: First Hand Report from COP21, with Judy Schwartz and Tom Goreau

results.description:
The truth is, this cookbook was what originally inspired the idea of a cookbook club. The moment I had this book in my hands, I couldn't wait to get in the kitchen and play with the recipes. The only problem was, there was no one else to enjoy the food with me! Sadly, my husband didn't share the same enthusiasm for such gorgeous vegetarian recipes.


A cookbook like this needs to be celebrated with the right people. It exudes inspiration and creativity on every page. I couldn't ask for a better group of home cooks to experience this book with. Plus, after the holiday season, I figured a vegetarian cookbook would be a refreshing choice for us. Get ready for yet another amazing feast!


Join me and your fellow cookbook collectors for our 4th feast! You can order the cookbook online or see if a local retailer has a copy. Note :: You don't have to buy a copy of the cookbook in order to participate in our events—email me and I'll hook you up. Check your library or ask a friend to borrow their copy.


NOTE :: Location in Salem MA to be announced soon (near MBTA station).

• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • •

INSTRUCTIONS :: How the Cookbook Club Works

1. Join our Meetup group! All cooking levels are welcome. Don't be shy.

2. RSVP via Meetup. Note :: Each of our "feast" events will happen the 1st Sunday of every month (except for January 2016, obviously), focusing on a different cookbook, and hosted at a new location in the North Shore. Everything will be organized by me, but you're more than welcome to offer suggestions of some of your favorite cookbooks.

3. Grab yourself a copy of the featured cookbook (ask your library, borrow from a friend, order online or purchase at a local retailer) and experiment with a few of the recipes.

4. Pick 1 recipe that you will make for the event. Be sure to read through all of the instructions to make sure you have the proper tools, dishes, and ingredients. (I made that mistake at the last feast.)


5. In the comments section below, share which recipe you will be bringing. I'll keep track of what everyone is bringing and make sure we don't have any overlaps. Note :: It might be wise to pick a backup recipe in case your 1st choice is already taken.

6. Day of the event. Prepare your recipe according to the directions provided in the cookbook. Source ingredients locally, if you can. As tempting as it might be to alter the recipe or make a substitution, please follow the instructions as closely as possible. This will allow the group to truly experience the author's array of recipes. I'll bring salt + pepper, just in case (thanks Barbara for the suggestion).


7. Come to the event with an open mind and empty stomach! Together we will feast on your wonderful food and share our experiences with one another. Bring your cookbook in order to highlight certain pages or make notes on recipes you especially loved. Post-it notes and pencils are provided.

8. If you feel inspired to bring fancier serving dishes (for the photos), I won't stop you! But it's not essential . . . just more fun.

9. Don't forget to bring a few small containers to take home leftovers. You'll have the best lunch that following Monday, guaranteed.


• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • •

WHAT'S INCLUDED :: (Stuff you don't have to worry about.)

1. Tables + Chairs

2. Linens, Tableware + Utensils

3. Serving Utensils

4. Non-Alcoholic beverages + cups. Note :: If you want to bring a wine or beer to share, please feel free to do so!

5. Photographer (me or my friend, Paul — pictures to be used mainly for our group photo album)

• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • •

TIPS + IDEAS :: (From our fellow cookbook collectors)

1. Go out of your comfort zone. Try a new technique or work with ingredients you've never used before. Bring the final dish, regardless of the outcome—good or bad—and let everyone learn from your experience! (Thank you Renee for this suggestion.)

2. There's no guarantee your dish will remain HOT by the time we are ready to eat. Consider recipes that not only travel well, but also can be served at room temperature. Either way, you're welcome to bring your own heating elements, crock pots, or warmers. I just can't guarantee there will always be an outlet accessible.


3. If you come across a cookbook that would be great for the group, snap a picture of the cover and send it to me ([masked]). Or you can bring a copy with you (like Lily did at the last feast) and see what the group thinks of it!

• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • •


IN CLOSING . . .


Many of the members in this groups are super excited to be participating in our feasts. So, if you're lucky enough to reserve a spot on the list . . . please be sure you can actually make it to the event. I wouldn't want spots to be inadvertently reserved, while there might be other members willing to attend the event. Plus, it will help me get a more accurate head count for the venue (and for renting chairs). Thanks so much! —Jessica

results.description:
The oldest, established, permanent floating Community Walk in Cambridge and environs.

Please join the Fresh Pond Community walkers + five other meetup groups for this delightful sunset walk. 

Let's join 20+ walkers and some other walking groups for:

Over 3 years of reliable walking

Please note that this walk does not start at the same place as the other Fresh Pond walk.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.
results.name: Weekly Multigroup Community Walk at Fresh Pond + dinner at Shangri La 1/10 3:30

results.description:
Join the Fresh Pond Walking Community for our regular Sunday walk around Fresh Pond.   

Let's join regular walkers from surrounding towns + members of five other walking groups and 20+ walkers for this walk.  Walk is on, Rain or Shine.

Few things are more enjoyable than a nice walk and a chat at the end of a busy weekend.

Since May 2012, we've met with a few other meetup groups Let's join for a stroll in a beautiful setting.

We walk clockwise, so if you get there late, just start walking counter-clockwise and you'll run into us.

Parking on Huron Avenue is easy, since the "Permit Parking" rules don't apply on Sunday - just park in any spot on Huron Ave, there will be plenty of them.

If you're coming by bus, take the 71 or 73 bus from Harvard Square and get off at Aberdeen Ave. Walk all the way up Aberdeen until you come to Huron Avenue, we'll be there.

Afterwards, we'll go out for dinner. We usually go for some unusual Chinese food, and the total cost is about $10 per person.

If you have trouble finding us, call me at[masked]

results.description:
Please note - this event is cross-posted here: http://www.meetup.com/Boston-Choral-Music-Meetup/events/227888546/ Kindly only RSVP on one meetup group. 

TICKET UPDATE: Tickets NOW $15 for this meetup >>>


Through the generosity of Cathedral Church of St Paul Music Director, Jessica Rucinski, tickets will be $15 per person (discounted from $30). To reserve your ticket at this special price for Boston CLASSICAL Music Meetup, please RSVP as yourself or with a +1 or more. We'll use this list and count (no need to specify number of tickets in your comments... just RSVP with the correct number). Your ticket will be at Will Call for $15. THANK YOU, Jessica!

------

The American Boychoir will stop in Boston on its national tour this year. Widely recognized as one of the finest musical ensembles in the country, the Boychoir performs regularly with world-class musical ensembles, including the New York Philharmonic, the Philadelphia Orchestra, and the Boston Symphony Orchestra. The American Boychoir is the cornerstone of the American Boychoir School (“ABS”), one of a small handful of boychoir schools in this country, and the only one committed to a national touring program. Boys from the Boychoir are frequently featured performers on radio programs for NPR and other public stations. The American Boychoir was also featured in the recent motion picture Boychoir, starring Dustin Hoffman and Kathy Bates. The Boston concert will be held at the Cathedral Church of St. Paul, 138 Tremont Street in downtown Boston on Sunday, January 10, 2016, at 4:00 p.m. Advance tickets (adults $30, students/seniors $15) can be purchased at www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2464552. For more information on the Boston concert, please email [masked]
results.name: The famous American Boychoir: national tour stop in Boston

results.description:
Give yourself the gift of relaxation and rejuvenation with a wonderful 90 minute gentle yoga and meditation class.

True relaxation is experienced by the body and mind when little or no energy is consumed. It is Nature's way of recharging. Since every action, conscious or unconscious, uses stored energy, relaxation is necessary for good health and peace of mind. Without proper relaxation the body and mind become overworked and inefficient.

When the mind is constantly bombarded by stimuli, it becomes overloaded and exhausted. We may be unaware that we are doing it, but by thinking and worrying we are using up tremendous amounts of energy. The tension put on the mind by worries can use more energy than physical work.

Yoga retrains the body to relax and can calm the mind which leads to inner peace.

This class is for beginners and experienced yogi's.  Chairs are available for those who may need to sit during this class.  Please bring your own yoga mat, water and a blanket or pillow for meditation.
results.name: Gentle Yoga & Meditation - 90 minute class

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

http://atwys2016bostonspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.
results.name: Speeddating Ages 37-47 --SOLD OUT FOR WOMEN

results.description:
This is an ongoing weekly (donation only) class for anyone, offering experiential practice in meditation, along with an opportunity to be among others interested in deepening spiritutual practices.  The class provides you with a felt sense of your own divinity; your Higher Self. The meditation, based on Kriya practices,  is partly guided, partly silent. In the guided part we open up to the flow of golden light and energy that is always pouring down to our body/mind/heart and being. Accessing that flow and inviting it to fill us brings a profound level of openness, while washing away limiting thoughts, feelings and beliefs. This higher vibration of unconditional love serves to open our consciousness to new levels of peace, joy and awakening. Bringing the flow of light into the body/mind/heart means we more consciously embody our Light Being, so we are more present, happy, forgiving, peaceful and joyful while in the world.
   After the guided portion we spend time in peaceful silence.  Whether you are an experienced meditator or a beginner, you will love the sweetness and powerful energies of this group. At the end of the class we make time for questions or sharing.  Group meditation is powerful, and it's refreshing to be among fellow travelers!
   Judy also teaches the Sound and Light meditation; a way for you to draw your senses inward to open your spiritual eye and to hear the sounds of your chakras. 
   This practice is non-denominational, appropriate for anyone. 
   Held in a lovely healing space, just walking in will bring you instant peace.  All are welcome.
    You may also want to check out my other Meetup, for a variety of spiritual programs:  http://www.meetup.com/Evolving-Beings/

At around 7:45...we'll head to a bar or not. Either way, you'll leave with API access to NFL, NBA, and NHL live stats and some new data tricks.

results.description:
"Men from children nothing differ."  --from Much Ado About Nothing

Much Ado About Nothing is a comedic play thought to have been written in 1598 and 1599, as Shakespeare was approaching the middle of his career. It was included in the First Folio, published in 1623. Much Ado About Nothing is generally considered one of Shakespeare's best comedies, because it combines elements of robust hilarity with more serious meditations on honor, shame, and court politics. By means of "noting" (which, in Shakespeare's day, sounded the same as "nothing," and which is gossip, rumour, and overhearing), much is transformed in the play.
results.how_to_find_us: Library (to the left of the entrance)

Anyone who want to learn different languages and different cultures are welcome to join us.

Wengang
